Application of ammonium acetate as a dual rule reagent-catalyst in synthesis of new symmetrical terpyridines Morteza Torabi a Mohammad Ali Zolfigol a ⁎ Meysam Yarie a ⁎ Yanlong Gu b a Department of Organic Chemistry, Faculty of Chemistry, Bu-Ali Sina University, Hamedan 6517838683, Iran Department of Organic Chemistry Faculty of Chemistry Bu-Ali Sina University Hamedan 6517838683 Iran aDepartment of Organic Chemistry, Faculty of Chemistry, Bu-Ali Sina University, Hamedan 6517838683, Iran b School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Huazhong University of Science and Technology, 1037 Luoyu road, Hongshan District, Wuhan 430074, China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Huazhong University of Science and Technology 1037 Luoyu road, Hongshan District Wuhan 430074 China bSchool of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Huazhong University of Science and Technology, 1037 Luoyu road, Hongshan District, Wuhan 430074, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Herein, we present a green, efficient and simple synthetic route to the new symmetrical terpyridines by using ammonium acetate (NH4OAc) as catalytically active reagent. Various techniques including Fourier transform infrared (FT‐IR) spectroscopy, 1H NMR, 13C NMR and Mass analysis have been applied for characterization of synthesized molecules. Moreover, a cooperative vinylogous anomeric-based oxidation pathway is suggested for the aromatization of titled molecules both under air and inert atmospheres. Graphical abstract Synthesis of novel symmetrical terpyridines using NH4OAc as both reagent and catalyst. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Anomeric effect Ammonium acetate Indole Terpyridines Vinylogous anomeric-based oxidation 1 Introduction Pyridine families represent a widespread class of nitrogen-containing heterocyclic scaffolds in biologically relevant molecules and plays a central role in the preparation of many bioactive compounds, natural products, functional materials and pharmaceutical agents [1–3]. Preventing or inducing apoptosis, antiasthmatic, antidepressant and inhibiting HIV protease are just a small number of the medicinal applications of pyridine derivatives [4–7]. Also, pyridine derivatives are useful ligands in varied catalytic organic transformations [8–9]. Different approaches such as condensation and aromatization of various carbonyl compounds or α,β-unsaturated derivatives of carbonyl compounds with ammonia [10–11], metal-catalyzed cyclization reactions [12–13] have been reported for the synthesis of pyridines in last decades. Also, organocatalytic synthesis of complex pyridine systems have been received widespread attentions [14]. In recent years, among pyridine derivatives, terpyridines have found a dramatically wide range of applications. Undoubtedly, these compounds are known as one of the most important classes of multi-dentate ligands [15]. These molecules with π-π stacking interactions have an essential role in the formation of supramolecular assemblies and possess a rigid backbone to form extended networks [16–18]. Due to the above-mentioned facts, these systems have been widely used in linear polynuclear metal complexes [19], and metallomacrocycles such as catenanes and molecular cages [20–21]. Also, extended applications for terpyridines such as cancer therapy [22], catalytic applications [17], self-healing materials [23], chemical probes [24] and chemical sensors [25] are reported. Due to great importance of terpyridines, different synthetic strategies for the synthesis of these compound have been reported [26–28]. For the most of these synthetic methods toxic and expensive organic solvents, such as pyridine and organohalides have been used [29]. The synthesis of terpyridines under solvent-free conditions and one-pot manner is a promising approach from the green synthesis view point [30]. Developing a green and drastic methodology is one of the major domains of synthetic chemistry. NH4OAc is a green, shelf-stable and safe reagent which has been applied in varied synthetic protocols as nitrogen source [31]. Moreover, NH4OAc can efficiently catalyzed the multi-component reactions under mild and green conditions [32]. Sometimes, the catalytic application of NH4OAc is better than strong bases or acids such as triethylamine, potassium carbonate, p-toluene sulfonic acid and hydrochloric acid [33]. We have introduced NH4OAc as dual rule reagent-catalyst in 2004 [34]. Some applications of NH4OAc both as reagent or catalyst are exhibited in Scheme 1 . Stereoelectronic effects as stabilizing interactions of orbitals through space can be categorized as conjugation, hyperconjugation, and σ‐conjugation. These interactions are based on a set of accepted rules that build a bridge between structure and reactivity at the susceptible molecules (Scheme 2 ) [44]. Hyperconjugation is classified as negative, positive, and neutral. Usually, positive hyperconjugation, involves the sharing electron density from a σ-orbital to a cationic center an empty orbital. Generally, negative hyperconjugation (anomeric effect) involves sharing the electron density from a lone pair to an acceptor σ*-orbital. Neutral hyperconjugation is a mutual doner-acceptor between σ and π-orbitals (σC-Y→π*C = X or πC=X→σ*C-Y for C = X-C-Y systems). It should be noted that the hydrogen bonding and anomeric effect are other features of negative hyperconjugation (Inter and intramolecular) (Scheme 3 ) [44]. Recently, we have comprehensively showed that the hetero atoms have stereoelectronic effects of common origin and that anomeric effect is one of them [45]. The anomeric interactions that extended through double bonds have been named as vinylogous anomeric effect. In Scheme 4 , geminal anomeic effect is compared with the vinylogous anomeric effect [44]. Recently, we have introduced the term “anomeric-based oxidation” (ABO) [46], which has been mini-reviewed [47]. A cooperative vinylogous anomeric-based oxidation and NH4OAc as catalytically active reagent are considered simultaneously for proposing a rational mechanism in the discussion part of the presented work. In this investigation, NH4OAc used as catalytically active reagent for the synthesis of new symmetrical terpyridines with indole moieties (Scheme 5 ). Also, we suggest a cooperative vinylogous anomeric-based oxidation manner [48–49] for the synthesis of titled molecules. 2 Results and discussion Due to the great importance of terpyridines, the synthesis of these compounds deserves more attentions and is of interest to our research group. Therefore, with the potential of NH4OAc as both reagent and catalyst, we are going to synthesis new series of symmetrical terpyridines with indole moieties. Furthermore, according to the Alabugin's theory, which has introduced stereoelectronic effects as a bridge between structure and reactivity [50], the anomeric effect and catalytic role of acetic acid (from thermal dissociation of ammonium acetate) were considered simultaneously for proposing a rational reaction mechanism. At the beginning of experimental section, we synthesized 1,1′-(2,6-dimethylpyridine-3,5-diyl)bis(ethan-1-one) (ke1) via a new and green procedure. After that, to gaining the best reaction conditions, we select the reaction of ke1, 4-cholorobenzaldehyde and 3-(1H-indol-3-yl)−3-oxopropanenitrile as a model reaction and in the presence of different amounts of NH4OAc as catalytically active reagent. Therefore, we used 2, 4, 6 and 8 mmol of NH4OAc for the model reaction. Finally, according to the obtained yields, 6 mmol of NH4OAc was the best of choice. Then, the parameter of temperature was investigated in model reaction. According to the results, in low temperatures such as 70 and 80 °C, NH4OAc was not activated completely. However, the reaction in 100 °C as optimized temperature, gave better yields of corresponding symmetrical terpyridine. Finally, the model reaction was performed in different solvents that have not good results. Also, the observed results from the testing of the model reaction under nitrogen, argon and air atmospheres are similar (Table 1 ). Based on these data, the best results were obtained by using 6 mmol of NH4OAc as catalytically active reagent under solvent free conditions at 100 °C. After finding the optimum reaction conditions, the catalytic performance of NH4OAc was investigated in more detail for the synthesis desired symmetrical terpyridines with indole moieties. So, different aromatic aldehydes with electron withdrawing and electron releasing substituents were applied under optimal reaction conditions. All corresponding molecules were synthesized with relatively good yields and short reaction times (Table 2 ). In another study, to confirm the abilities of NH4OAc and its efficiency in the reaction process, we precisely compared catalytic activity of NH4OAc with other ammonia source. For this purpose, the model reaction was performed in the presence of ammonium sources such as: (NH4)2C2O4, (NH4)2CO3, NH4F, NH4HCO3, NH4HCO2, NH4H2PO4, NH4Cl and NH4NO3 instead of NH4OAc. The obtained experimental data revealed that, compared to other ammonia sources, NH4OAc has led to better results. The achieved experimental results are included in Table 3 . Also, we suggest a hypothetical mechanism for synthesis of 1a as displayed in Scheme 6 . Initially, carbonyl groups of ke1 are activated by AcOH (derived from thermal dissociation of ammonium acetate) and reacted with ammonia which leads to related imine intermediate A. Then, via a tautomerization process, intermediate A converted to intermediate B. Meanwhile, intermediate C is obtained from a Knoevenagel condensation reaction between 4-cholorobenzaldehyde and 3-(1H-indol-3-yl)−3-oxopropanenitrile. After that, intermediate B reacts with intermediate C which results to formation of intermediate D. In the next step, through successive tautomerization process, and intramolecular nucleophilic attack intermediate E is formed. In the next step, intermediate E through dehydration converted to the related intermediate F. Finally, the corresponding product (1a) is produced via a cooperative vinylogous anomeric based oxidation mechanism both in the presence and absence of oxygen ( Scheme 6) [51–52]. It should be mentioned that, the reaction in the absence of oxygen and under both nitrogen and argon atmospheres were proceeded as same as in the presence of oxygen. In the course of our investigation, besides of molecules 1i, we tried to synthesize other series of pyridine systems (such as molecules 2i and 3i). After performing the relevant reactions, we found that the desired molecules were not obtained. In these cases, it is suggested that the steric effects of phenyl ring in ketone (ke2) and deactivation of carbonyl groups in ketone (ke3) through the resonance with the nitrogen lone pair, prevented the synthesis of targeted products. Scheme 7 3 Experimental section 3.1 General procedure for the synthesis of ke1 Initially, formaldehyde (37% aqueous solution, 3.75 ml, 50 mmol,), acetylacetone (20.026 g, 200 mmol), NH4OAc (7.7 g, 100 mmol) and water (100 mL) were added to a 250 mL flask and the mixture was refluxed for 3 h while vigorously stirring. After completing of reaction, the mixture was filtrated off and the formed yellow precipitate of 1,1′-(2,6-dimethyl-1,4-dihydropyridine-3,5-diyl)bis(ethan-1-one) was washed with cold water and ethanol respectively. The solid was dried under air conditions (yield: 95% and MP: 207–209 °C). Then, 1,1′-(2,6-dimethyl-1,4-dihydropyridine-3,5-diyl)bis(ethan-1-one) (1.93 g, 10 mmol) and sodium nitrite (1.38 g, 20 mmol) was dissolved in 50 mL of ethanol/water (1/1, V/V) and heated in 60 °C for 15 min. Then, acetic acid (21 mmol, 1.2 mL) was added dropwise to the reaction mixture and refluxed for 5 h. After that, the solvent was evaporated and remained solid was washed with water to give ke1 (yield: 85% and MP: 70–72 °C). 3.2 General procedure for the synthesis of symmetrical terpyridines in the presence of NH4OAc A mixture of aromatic aldehydes (2 mmol), ke1 (1 mmol, 0.191 g), 3-(1H-indol-3-yl)−3-oxopropanenitrile (2 mmol, 0.368 g) or ethyl cyanoacetate (2 mmol, 0.216) and NH4OAc (6 mmol, 0.462 g) was subjected to the reaction at 100 °C under solvent-free conditions for requisite times (Table 2). The progress of reaction was checked out by TLC techniques (n-hexane/ethylacetate as eluent). After completions of each reaction, the reaction mixture was washed with water to removing excess amount of NH4OAc. Then, remained solid was washed with cold ethanol or ethanol/water (10/1, V/V) several times to give pure products. 3.3 Spectral data 1,1′-(2,6-Dimethylpyridine-3,5-diyl)bis(ethan-1-one) (ke1) M.p. = 70–72 °C, FT‐IR (KBr, ν, cm−1): 3000, 2926, 1680, 1594, 1530, 1358. 1H NMR (301 MHz, DMSO) δ 8.53 (s, 1H, Aromatic), 2.66 (s, 6H, CH3), 2.63 (s, 6H, CH3). 13C NMR (76 MHz, DMSO) δ 200.6, 159.2, 138.9, 130.3, 30.3, 24.8. 6,6′'-Di(1H-indol-3-yl)−2′,6′-dimethyl-4,4′'-diphenyl-[2,3′:5′,2′'-terpyridine]−5,5′'-dicarbonitrile (1a) M.p. = 197–199 °C, FT‐IR (KBr, ν, cm−1): 3325, 2927, 2219, 1565, 1527, 1438, 1232. 1H NMR (301 MHz, DMSO) δ 11.95 (s, 2H, NH), 8.45–8.44 (m, 3H, Aromatic), 8.34 (d, J = 6 Hz, 2H, Aromatic), 7.86–7.83 (m, 4H, Aromatic), 7.78 (s, 2H, Aromatic), 7.66–7.61 (m, 6H, Aromatic), 7.55 (d, J = 6 Hz, 2H, Aromatic), 7.23 – 7.17 (m, 2H, Aromatic), 7.08–7.03 (m, 2H, Aromatic), 2.78 (s, 6H, CH3). 13C NMR (76 MHz, DMSO) δ 160.1, 157.5, 156.3, 155.3, 139.6, 137.1, 136.9, 132.4, 130.3, 129.5, 129.4, 129.3, 126.4, 122.9, 122.0, 121.2, 120.8, 119.3, 113.2, 112.6, 101.7, 24.0. MHz, DMSO) δ 162.2, 160.4, 157.1, 149.4, 139.2, 130.7, 126.6, 117.3, 116.09, 112.5, 108.5, 23.4. 4 Conclusion In summary, we introduced an efficient and green procedure for the synthesis of new symmetrical terpyridines using NH4OAc as a catalytically active reagent through a straightforward synthetic manner. Several techniques such as FT‐IR, 1H NMR, 13C NMR and Mass analysis was applied for exact characterization of targeted molecules. Moreover, we suggested a cooperative vinylogous anomeric-based oxidations for the aromatization of heterocycle molecules under air and inert atmosphere. To the best of our knowledge, NH4OAc is the best source for in-situ generation of ammonia in the course of reaction. We think that the described green methodology is applicable in the reactions that ammonia is one of the starting materials. coredata.dc:description: Herein, we present a green, efficient and simple synthetic route to the new symmetrical terpyridines by using ammonium acetate (NH4OAc) as catalytically active reagent. Various techniques including Fourier transform infrared (FT‐IR) spectroscopy, 1H NMR, 13C NMR and Mass analysis have been applied for characterization of synthesized molecules. Moreover, a cooperative vinylogous anomeric-based oxidation pathway is suggested for the aromatization of titled molecules both under air and inert atmospheres.
coredata.dc:title: Application of ammonium acetate as a dual rule reagent-catalyst in synthesis of new symmetrical terpyridines
